ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How physiology impacts evolution and ecology and vice versa!
An understanding and appreciation for physiological mechanisms throughout the animal kingdom

I learned about how organismal physiology is the product of complex interactions between ecology, evolution, and the environment.  There are so many bafflingly wonderful quirks and metabolic processes I had the chance to learn about in this class.
Information regarding evolution and physiology.
I learned a ton about the unifying principles that connect animal physiology, how to think more clearly and succinctly, and just a ton of interesting animal facts.
I learned not only about the main topics in evolutionary biology, but how they are vulnerable to ongoing events such as climate change.

I learned about physiological topics across very diverse swaths of biological life from macroscopic to microscopic scales. I gained insight into thinking about physiology in the context of ecology and evolution.
I learned about processes in comparative physiology from the cell to organism level, with many examples in animals.
Wow! So many cool biology facts. Really deepened my understanding of evolution maybe moreso than my understanding of physiology.
Critical thinking, and being more open minded and content with theories that may not have a right/wrong answer.
Animal physiology spanning the molecular-level, body systems level, and environmental level, through the lens of evolutionary context and history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It covers science basics so everyones on the same page before getting to the material for the day which helps so much, serving as either review or a quick sum up of what you need to understand whats coming. All the examples were super interesting and helped provide ways to understand material that wasn't just memorizing facts and definitions but just finding out cool things nature does and how.

Lectures were clear, concise, and a joy to participate in.  Discussion sections were also extremely helpful in clarifying any concepts and resolving confusion.  One or two classes might have been a bit rushed, but the class proceeds at a very manageable pace overall.
Strength: Professor Munoz! Her lectures are so engaging and she is probably the best lecturer at Yale. She is also super understanding and friendly

I don't think this class has any weaknesses at all. Content was presented at a perfect rate and the weekly quizzes/written assignments were a great way to apply the knowledge we learned. The two midterms felt very fair and allowed you think about content in new ways. I know some people didn't love the grading scheme (each point on an assignment equates to one point of your final grade) but I thought it made figuring out how I had done very simple.

The entire teaching team was incredible. Prof. Muoz approached this course with so much care, compassion, and enthusiasm which made this course outstanding. I appreciated the format of the course with biweekly quizzes and assignments to keep us up to date on the content.

One weakness of the course is that sometimes the content could have been ordered slightly differently to facilitate learning. It often felt like we weren't learning discrete units, which on the one hand I appreciate since all of the concepts that we were learning are connected in some ways, but it did make it a little harder to study.

I think this course has many strengths. The professor was very passionate, the TA was very helpful, and the course was well-taught. I think that the point system made the grading a bit less representative of a student's knowledge since if you got a few questions wrong on an exam, you would already be in a B range.

Strengths: amazing lectures, manageable workload and good format (quizzes, assignments, two exams), great professor and TF. 
Weaknesses: I thought the discussion section was unnecessary and usually not a great use of time (also it was at 8:20am on Monday morning!)

I have no complaints. This class was AMAZING. 
Strengths: Dr. Muoz is a force of nature. She is energetic, caring, and lightning quick. She knows how to connect with students and her teaching style lectures with some breakout exercises. The assignments are very fair though the first exam felt too long for the time we had.

Strengths were that all the content was interesting and easy to understand by the professor 
Weakness was that the slides were not easy to understand unless you attended the lecture which makes it difficult if you have to miss a class or reviewing slides

The case studies explored in the course were very engaging and memorable ways to engage with the course's topics of focus. Compared to other biology courses, this course also emphasized conceptual knowledge more than memorization, which is a big strength of the course for me.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
yes! super interesting content and prof.Muoz is amazing
I would strongly recommend this course to any student with an interest in ecology and evolutionary biology.

Yes!  It's a great way to learn more about fundamental biological processes--respiration, muscle movement, thermoregulation--that all life undertakes.  If nothing else, you have the chance to simply take in all the wonders of the natural world.  The class deepens your appreciation for all the improbable evolutionary twists and turns that makes all the stunningly diverse creatures on our planet what they are.
Yes.
Yes, even though this was a required major course it was my favorite course of the semester. It was interesting and engaging but covered a ton of important content as well.

Absolutely! You learn so much about the animal world and come out each time with a sense of awe for how cool our planet is. Dr. Munoz is an absolute gem and simply being in the class to hear her is worth it.
I absolutely would, if the student is interested in E&EB. I took this course only because it was required for my track in the major, but I do think it's very well taught and structured.
I would! It was refreshing to take a course that was taught with such interest and passion.
Yes -- it's well taught and is a great opportunity to learn about cool topics and get to think curiously and critically about physiology!
yes
Yes! A great E&EB elective.
Yes you learn a lot of cool animal facts but you also learn physiology

YES! Though I am an E&EB major, a number of my friends took it for fun and really enjoyed the course. The class moves very quickly so a basis in biology is necessary. There is some overlap with comparative anatomy but Dr. Muoz takes you leaps and bounds beyond into the wonderful world of physiology. Take this class!
Yes if it matches their interests, it's a very informative course

Yes, Professor Muoz is an extremely engaging lecturer and her passion for biology is contagious. This course is a great way to explore the power of evolutionary thinking and the wide range of diversity in organisms.
